unnormalised: Subject: Air Quality: Are we breathing easy in India?
normalised: Subject: Air Quality: Are we breathing easy in India?

unnormalised: Lately, I've been seriously concerned about air quality, especially living in a bustling city like Delhi. I mean, some days you can practically *taste* the air, you know?
normalised: Lately, I've been seriously concerned about air quality, especially living in a bustling city like Delhi. I mean, some days you can practically taste the air, you know?

unnormalised: How bad is it, really? Well, according to the CPCB (Central Pollution Control Board), a lot of our cities are consistently above the safe limits. We're talking about PM2.5 and PM10 levels that would make your head spin. Remember that Diwali night on 24/10/2022? The air quality went off the charts!
normalised: How bad is it, really? Well, according to the C P C B (Central Pollution Control Board), a lot of our cities are consistently above the safe limits. We're talking about P M two point five and P M ten levels that would make your head spin. Remember that Diwali night on twenty fourth october two thousand and twenty two? The air quality went off the charts!

unnormalised: It's not just a Delhi problem either. Cities like Kanpur, Patna, and even smaller towns are struggling. I read a report stating that air pollution reduces life expectancy by several years in some parts of Uttar Pradesh. Quite scary, right?
normalised: It's not just a Delhi problem either. Cities like Kanpur, Patna, and even smaller towns are struggling. I read a report stating that air pollution reduces life expectancy by several years in some parts of Uttar Pradesh. Quite scary, right?

unnormalised: What can we do? The government is trying, with initiatives like the National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), but it's a massive challenge. Things like promoting electric vehicles (EVs), improving public transport, and implementing stricter emission norms are key. The IIT-Kanpur is doing some amazing research on solutions, so there's hope.
normalised: What can we do? The government is trying, with initiatives like the National Clean Air Programme (N C A P), but it's a massive challenge. Things like promoting electric vehicles (E V s), improving public transport, and implementing stricter emission norms are key. The I I T-Kanpur is doing some amazing research on solutions, so there's hope.

unnormalised: Personally, I've started using an air purifier at home, especially since I have elderly relatives who are more vulnerable. I also try to avoid peak traffic times (like during 09:00 hrs or 18:00 hrs) and cycle or walk whenever possible. Every little bit helps!
normalised: Personally, I've started using an air purifier at home, especially since I have elderly relatives who are more vulnerable. I also try to avoid peak traffic times (like during zero nine hundred hours or eighteen hundred hours) and cycle or walk whenever possible. Every little bit helps!
